Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: Management needs firm estimates for the quarterly roadmap and is awaiting their input
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, spreadsheets and Gantt charts glowing on the screen. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Quarterly estimates due by 8 PM.” I glanced at the clock—7:15. My mind raced through dependencies, risks, and the pressure to get it right. Just then, my husband walked in, dropping his bag with a sigh. “Rough day,” he said, voice tired but casual. I knew that tone—he wanted to talk, maybe just a hug, maybe more. I wanted to close the laptop, to listen, to be the supportive wife he deserved. But the project plan was unfinished, and management was waiting. If I missed this deadline, the whole team would be affected. My heart tugged in two directions: toward him, needing comfort, and toward my work, needing precision. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing in, my fingers hovering over the keyboard, my eyes flicking between his face and the screen, torn by the impossible choice.
